definition: The hard parts inside your body that help you stand up and give you shape.
example: You can feel the hard bones in your fingers and arms.

definition: A structure that holds something together and gives it shape.
example: Your skeleton acts like a frame for your whole body.

definition: The large bone at the top of your leg that helps you walk and bend.
example: When you put your hands on your waist, you are near your hips.

definition: The bones in your face that hold your teeth and help you chew.
example: You move your jaw up and down when you talk and eat.

definition: A small copy of something real that helps us learn about it.
example: Our teacher showed us a plastic model of a human skeleton.

definition: The bones in your chest that curve around to keep your heart and lungs safe.
example: Your rib cage is like a shield protecting your important organs.

definition: All the bones in a body joined together to form a frame.
example: A human skeleton helps us stand tall and move.

definition: The big, hard bone in your head that protects your brain.
example: Your skull is like a strong helmet for your brain.

definition: The line of many small bones going all the way down your back.
example: Your spine helps you bend and stand up straight.

definition: The special job or work that something is made to do.
example: The function of your heart is to pump blood around your body.

definition: A measurement of how long something is from one end to the other.
example: We used a ruler to measure the length of our arm bones.

definition: The soft parts in your body that pull on bones to make you move.
example: You use muscles in your legs to run and jump.

definition: Special parts inside your body that do very important jobs.
example: Your brain, heart, and lungs are all organs.

definition: To keep something safe so that it does not get hurt.
example: Your skeleton helps to protect your soft organs inside.

definition: To hold something up and stop it from falling down.
example: Your spine gives support to your whole body.

definition: To become shorter and tighter.
example: When you bend your arm, your bicep muscle contracts.

definition: To become loose or less tight.
example: When you straighten your arm, your bicep muscle relaxes.

definition: A hard, protective shell on the *outside* of an animal's body.
example: A beetle or a crab has a hard exoskeleton.

definition: A set of questions that helps you figure out the name of a living thing.
example: We used an identification key to find out what kind of insect we found.

definition: An animal that does *not* have a spine or backbone.
example: A jellyfish, a worm, and a spider are all invertebrates.

definition: An animal that *has* a spine or backbone.
example: Fish, birds, dogs, and humans are all vertebrates.

definition: Very tiny living things, like bacteria, that can get inside your body and make you sick.
example: We wash our hands with soap to get rid of germs.

definition: When germs get into your body and start to make you sick.
example: A cough can spread germs that infect other people.

definition: A sickness that can easily pass from one person to another person.
example: The flu is an infectious disease that spreads quickly in winter.

definition: A list of steps that tell you how to do something correctly and safely.
example: You must always follow the instructions on the medicine bottle.

definition: Special substances, like pills or liquids, you take to help your body fight a sickness.
example: The doctor gave me medicines to help my cough get better.

definition: To stop something bad from happening *before* it starts.
example: Washing your hands helps prevent getting sick.

definition: A shot (injection) that teaches your body how to fight off a disease so you don't get sick.
example: Babies get vaccinations to protect them from serious illnesses.

definition: The power that makes things move, grow, or change.
example: You get energy from food so you can run and play.

definition: To make a smart guess about what you think will happen next in an experiment.
example: I predict the toy car will roll faster down the taller ramp.

definition: The final part of an experiment where you explain what you learned.
example: Our conclusion was that the plant kept in the dark did not grow.

definition: The movement of energy from one object or place to another.
example: When you eat an apple, energy transfers from the apple to you.

definition: To break something completely so it is gone.
example: Energy cannot be created or destroyed, it just changes form.

definition: Machines that must be plugged in to use electricity for their job.
example: A toaster, a fan, and a TV are all electrical appliances.

definition: The energy that flows through wires to power things like lights and fans.
example: A lamp changes electrical energy into light energy.

definition: An animal that eats only other animals (meat).
example: A lion is a carnivore because it hunts and eats zebras.

definition: An animal that eats both plants and animals.
example: A bear is an omnivore because it eats berries and fish.

definition: A living thing that must eat other living things to get energy.
example: A rabbit (eats plants) and a fox (eats rabbits) are both consumers.

definition: An animal that hunts other animals for food.
example: An owl is a predator that hunts mice at night.

definition: A drawing that shows how energy passes from plants to animals.
example: A simple food chain is: Grass (Producer) -> Rabbit (Consumer) -> Fox (Consumer).

definition: An animal that is hunted and eaten by another animal.
example: A mouse is prey for a cat.

definition: An animal that eats only plants.
example: A cow is a herbivore because it only eats grass.

definition: A living thing (usually a plant) that makes its own food using sunlight.
example: A flower is a producer because it uses sunlight to make energy.

definition: The special way plants use sunlight, water, and air to make their own food (sugar).
example: Photosynthesis is how a green leaf turns sunlight into energy to grow.

definition: The part of a plant that grows underground to hold the plant still and drink water.
example: A carrot is a large root that we can eat.

definition: The main body or stalk of a plant that holds up the leaves and flowers.
example: The stem acts like a straw, carrying water from the roots to the leaves.

definition: The flat, usually green parts of a plant that grow from the stem and make food.
example: Leaves soak up the sunshine to start photosynthesis.

definition: The small parts made by a plant that can grow into a new plant.
example: An apple has seeds inside it that can grow into a new apple tree.

definition: The process when a seed breaks open and starts to grow into a small plant.
example: We watched the bean seed's germination as a tiny root came out.

definition: The natural home or place where an animal or plant lives.
example: A hot, sandy desert is the habitat for a camel.

definition: A special body part or behavior that helps a living thing survive in its habitat.
example: A polar bear's thick white fur is an adaptation for living in the cold Arctic.

definition: All the living and non-living things that surround an organism.
example: We must keep our environment clean by not throwing trash on the ground.

definition: A warm-blooded vertebrate animal (like humans, dogs, whales) that has hair or fur and feeds milk to its babies.
example: A dolphin is a mammal that lives in the ocean.

definition: A cold-blooded vertebrate animal (like snakes, lizards, crocodiles) that has dry, scaly skin and lays eggs.
example: A turtle is a reptile with a hard shell to protect it.

definition: A cold-blooded vertebrate animal (like frogs, toads) that lives part of its life in water (with gills) and part on land (with lungs).
example: A frog is an amphibian that changes from a tadpole to an adult.

definition: A vertebrate animal that lives only in water, breathes with gills, and has fins for swimming.
example: A clownfish is a small, colorful fish that lives in the sea.

definition: A warm-blooded vertebrate animal that has feathers, wings, and lays eggs.
example: A penguin is a bird that cannot fly but is a great swimmer.

definition: A small invertebrate animal (like ants, beetles) with an exoskeleton, three body parts, and six legs.
example: A butterfly is a beautiful insect with colorful wings.

definition: All the changes a living thing goes through from when it is born until it is an adult.
example: The life cycle of a butterfly includes an egg, larva (caterpillar), pupa, and adult.

definition: A big change in the body shape of some animals as they grow up.
example: A tadpole turning into a frog is a type of metamorphosis.

definition: The parts on the side of a fish's head that it uses to breathe underwater.
example: A fish takes in oxygen from the water using its gills.

definition: The organs in your chest that fill with air when you breathe in.
example: You use your lungs to get oxygen from the air.

definition: The organ inside your skull that controls everything in your body, like thinking and moving.
example: Your brain is like the control center for your whole body.

definition: To break down food in your body so you can use it for energy.
example: Your stomach helps to digest the sandwich you ate for lunch.

definition: The process of getting the right food (like fruits and vegetables) that your body needs to grow and stay healthy.
example: Good nutrition is important for having lots of energy.

definition: The ways your body learns about the world around it (sight, hearing, smell, taste, and touch).
example: You use your five senses to see, hear, and feel the world.

definition: A group of very similar living things that can have babies together.
example: A tiger is a different species from a lion.

definition: When a whole species, or type of animal, has died and is gone forever.
example: Dinosaurs are extinct; there are none left alive today.

definition: The place or thing where energy comes from.
example: The Sun is the main source of light and heat energy for Earth.

definition: A form of energy that we can see, which travels in waves.
example: A light bulb changes electrical energy into light energy so we can see in the dark.

definition: A form of energy that makes things warm; it moves from hotter things to cooler things.
example: A fire gives off heat energy that keeps us warm.

definition: A form of energy we can hear, which is made by vibrations.
example: A drum makes sound energy when you hit it.

definition: A very fast movement back and forth that creates sound.
example: A guitar string makes a sound because of its vibration.

definition: The energy that something has *because* it is moving.
example: A bicycle rolling down a hill has a lot of kinetic energy.

definition: Energy that is stored up and ready to be used.
example: A stretched rubber band has potential energy before you let it go.

definition: A push or a pull on an object that can make it move, stop, or change shape.
example: You use a force to push a swing or pull a wagon.

definition: The invisible force that pulls everything down towards the center of the Earth.
example: Gravity is the force that makes an apple fall from a tree to the ground.

definition: A force that slows down moving objects when they rub against each other.
example: Friction between your shoes and the floor stops you from slipping.

definition: An object that can pull on certain metals, like iron, using a special force.
example: A magnet can pick up paperclips without touching them.

definition: When light bounces off a smooth, shiny surface.
example: You can see yourself in a mirror because it reflects light.

definition: Describes an object that light cannot pass through at all.
example: A wooden door is opaque because you cannot see through it.
vietnamese: Mờ đục (không cho ánh sáng đi qua)

definition: Describes an object that light can pass through clearly.
example: A glass window is transparent, so you can see the outside.

definition: Describes an object that lets *some* light pass through, but you cannot see clearly.
example: Frosted glass is translucent; you can see light but not shapes.
vietnamese: Mờ (cho một phần ánh sáng đi qua)

definition: A dark area made when an opaque object blocks the path of light.
example: You make a shadow on the ground when you stand in the sun.

definition: A complete, closed path that electricity can flow around.
example: The light bulb lit up when we finished the circuit.

definition: A source of stored electrical energy that can power things like toys and flashlights.
example: We put a new battery in the remote control so it would work.

definition: A thin piece of metal used to connect parts in an electrical circuit.
example: Electricity flows through the wire from the battery to the bulb.

definition: A glass object that makes light when electricity passes through it.
example: The bulb in the lamp helps us read at night.

definition: A part of a circuit that opens or closes the path for electricity.
example: You flip the light switch to turn the lights on or off.

definition: A material that lets electricity (or heat) pass through it easily.
example: Metal is a good conductor, which is why wires are made of copper.

definition: A material that does *not* let electricity (or heat) pass through it easily.
example: Rubber is a good insulator, which is why it covers wires to keep us safe.

definition: The electricity that comes from the power sockets (plugs) in the wall of your house.
example: A refrigerator is a big appliance that plugs into the mains.

definition: A living thing, like fungi or bacteria, that breaks down dead plants and animals.
example: Mushrooms are decomposers that help clean the forest floor.
